text: The Impact of Sharia Knowledge in Confronting Violence and Aggression. Prepared by Dr. Abdul Aziz bin Fawzan bin Saleh Al-Fawzan, Faculty Member at the College of Sharia, Imam Muhammad bin Saud Islamic University. In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Introduction: Praise be to Allah who guided us to Islam, and we would not have been guided had Allah not guided us. I bear witness that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah alone, having no partner; we have no Lord other than Him, and no true object of worship but Him. And I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant, His Messenger, His friend (Khalil), and His chosen one. May Allah send peace and blessings upon him, his family, his companions, and those who support him. To proceed: Security is an urgent human need and an innate requirement without which life cannot proceed correctly. No individual or society can do without it. Life without security is an arid, barren, harsh, and cruel life that cannot be accepted or endured. Security is one of the most important foundations of happiness and stability, and one of the most important causes of progress, civilization, and advancement. It is a demand upon whose importance all nations, peoples, individuals, and societies agree, in every time and place. If security is lost, souls become disturbed, fear and anxiety dominate them, people's interests are disrupted, they withdraw from striving and earning, and their concerns become limited to securing themselves and their dependents, and repelling injustice and aggression that is occurring or expected against them.

text: If security is an urgent human need that no individual or society can do without, this necessarily implies the obligation to confront violence that disrupts it, treat its effects, and cut off the causes leading to it. Islam has its unique approach to achieving security and combating violence. It focuses on the educational and preventive aspects that prevent the occurrence of violence in the first place, as well as the deterrent and punitive aspects that erase its effects and prevent its recurrence and repetition. This is contrary to what is found in pre-Islamic human methodologies and positive laws, which focus on treating violence after it occurs more than they focus on preventing its occurrence from the start.

text: Even if they were destined to focus on preventive and educational aspects, they would not possess the means for it, nor the commitment, response, and respect for it that are available to Divine legislation. This legislation is established by the Wise Creator who created man and knows what rectifies him and brings him happiness in his immediate and future affairs. It is a legislation free from human ignorance, human whims, human weakness, and human fluctuations. There is no favoritism in it for an individual, a class, or a race, because Allah is the Lord of the worlds, and all people are His servants. He revealed His law to them to achieve their security, preserve their interests, and guide them to what contains their happiness in this world and the Hereafter. In this research, I will focus on explaining the impact of Sharia knowledge in confronting violence. For indeed, Sharia knowledge founded on the Book and the Sunnah is what refines souls, purifies hearts, restricts its possessor from violence and crime, prevents him from injustice and aggression, compels him to honor the rights of people and preserve their interests, and restrains him from daring to violate sanctities and commit injustices and destructive sins. It prevents violence from the start, and it is also one of the greatest means assisting in the treatment of this dangerous phenomenon, and inducing those involved in it to repent, return to God, and not repeat or return to it.

text: Preface: The misguidance of creation, despite its many forms and types, and its multiple manifestations and shapes—whether in thoughts and perceptions, morals and behaviors, or actions and practices—returns in reality to two main causes: First: Ignorance or blindness. Second: Injustice or desire (hawā). text: This is also indicated by the fact that Allah Almighty commanded us to recite the Mother of the Quran (Al-Fatihah) in every rak'ah of prayer, whether obligatory or recommended. Among its verses is His saying, Glory be to Him: {Guide us to the straight path} {The path of those upon whom You have bestowed favor, not of those who have evoked [Your] anger or of those who are astray.} [Al-Fatihah: 6-7]. Thus, He guided us to ask Him for guidance to the straight path, and that implies knowing the truth and being successful in acting upon it, both of which negate ignorance and desire. Then He explained that this is the path of those upon whom He bestowed favor among the Prophets and their followers in excellence, as He guided them to the truth and aided them in complying with it and acting upon it. This is unlike those who evoked anger and those who went astray, who deviated from the straight path. Consequently, they fell into polytheism and misguidance, innovations and superstitions, and committed major sins and evil deeds. This was either due to following desires despite their knowledge of the truth—and these are the ones who evoked anger, like the Jews, whom Allah led astray knowingly, so they abandoned the truth while knowing it—or due to their ignorance of the truth, so they worshipped Allah based on ignorance—and these are the straying ones, like the Christians, who draw near to Him with polytheistic acts and worship Him with innovations and misguidance.

text: Many of those who commit major sins, indulge excessively in disobedience against themselves, or are lenient in oppressing people and diminishing their rights, do not know that their action is among the prohibited major sins. And if they know its prohibition in general terms, they do not realize its heinousness and the severity of its prohibition, nor the sin and bad omens that result from it, and the evil consequences in this world and in the Hereafter. For this reason, Allah Almighty made seeking Sharia knowledge an obligation upon every Muslim male and female. First Requirement: The Prohibition of Aggression Against the Self.
The human soul does not belong to the human; rather, it is the property of its Creator and Originator, the Almighty. It is a trust with its owner, and he will be asked about it on the Day of Resurrection: Did he preserve it and fulfill its rights, or did he waste it and wrong it, and fail to perform what is due to it? For this reason, it is not permissible for a person to kill himself, nor to expose it to danger without a legitimate interest, nor to dispose of any of its parts except in a way that brings benefit to it or wards off harm from it. He has no right to harm himself under the pretext that he is acting within what concerns him and that he has not assaulted anyone else, for his aggression against himself is like his aggression against another in the sight of Allah Almighty (1). Allah Almighty said: {And do not kill yourselves [or one another]. Indeed, Allah is to you ever Merciful.} {And whoever does that in aggression and injustice - We will drive him into a Fire. And that, for Allah, is [always] easy.} [An-Nisa: 29-30]. This is a prohibition for believers against killing one another (2), and a prohibition for a human against killing himself, whether by intentionally killing himself directly or by engaging in dangers leading to destruction and death. Then He threatened whoever kills himself or the soul of another without right that He will drive him into the fire of Hell, and what an evil destination (3).

text: Al-Qurtubi said: "The people of interpretation agreed that the meaning of this verse is the prohibition of people killing one another. Then, its wording encompasses a man killing himself with the intent of killing: out of greed for the world and seeking wealth, by driving himself into risks leading to destruction... or in a state of distress or anger; the prohibition covers all of this" (1). Amr bin Al-Aas, may Allah be pleased with him, used this verse as evidence when he entered a state of major impurity (Janabah) and then performed dry ablution (Tayammum), fearing that if he washed with water he would perish from the extreme cold. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, laughed and affirmed his reasoning (2). And Allah Almighty said: {And do not throw [yourselves] with your [own] hands into destruction} [Al-Baqarah: 195]. Throwing is casting a thing, and 'hands' refers to souls (selves), expressing the whole by the part, based on the fact that most actions of the soul are done by hands. 'Destruction' (Tahlukah) is a verbal noun from halaka (to perish)... meaning: do not cause yourselves to fall into destruction (3). text: Also in the two Sahihs, on the authority of Abu Huraira, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Whoever kills himself with a piece of iron, his piece of iron will be in his hand, stabbing (1) himself with it in his belly in the fire of Hell, abiding eternally therein forever. For by considering what Allah prohibited as lawful, he becomes a disbeliever, and the disbeliever abides eternally in the Fire without doubt. text: This Hadith indicates the prohibition of a human killing himself and the magnitude of his punishment in the Hereafter. It also indicates that whoever kills himself without considering it lawful is not considered a disbeliever (Kafir). Therefore, Al-Nawawi titled the chapter: "Chapter: Evidence that the one who kills himself does not become a disbeliever." He then said in the explanation of the Hadith: "It contains an argument for a great principle of Ahlus-Sunnah: that whoever kills himself, or commits any other sin, and dies without repentance, is not a disbeliever, nor is it definitively decided that he goes to the Fire; rather, he is subject to the Will [of Allah]... This Hadith is an explanation for the Hadiths before it whose apparent meaning suggests the eternal residence of the suicide and other committers of major sins in the Fire" (1). Just as it is not permissible to destroy the self completely, it is not permissible to cause it pain or destroy a limb from it, except for an interest that outweighs the harm of pain and amputation. If one needs to amputate a limb of his body, cauterize a part of it, or insert a needle into it for a benefit he hopes for his body or to ward off a harm he fears for it, there is no sin in that. This is because his interest returns to protecting the self, and it falls under the principle of committing the lesser of two harms to ward off the greater, or obtaining the higher of two benefits by forfeiting the lower. And Allah knows best.

Second Requirement: Prohibition of Human Aggression Against Others.
If a human's aggression against himself is of such severity in prohibition and intensity in punishment, then his aggression against others is even more severely prohibited, greater in sin, harsher in punishment, and worse in consequence. Many texts in the Book and the Sunnah have come warning against that with severe warning, explaining its evil consequence and the magnitude of the perpetrator's punishment. Allah Almighty said: {And do not kill the soul which Allah has forbidden, except by right} [Al-Isra: 33]. This verse is a prohibition against killing the forbidden soul, whether it is a believer or a covenanted person (Mu'ahid), except by the right that necessitates its killing (1). And Almighty said: {And never is it for a believer to kill a believer except by mistake} [An-Nisa: 92]. And Almighty said: {But whoever kills a believer intentionally - his recompense is Hell, wherein he will abide eternally, and Allah has become angry with him and has cursed him and prepared for him a great punishment} [An-Nisa: 93]. What threat is greater than this threat?! It is a threat from which the skins of believers shiver, and their hearts are torn from its horror. It creates in their souls a strong deterrent and an internal restraint preventing them from transgressing against others and taking their lives unjustly and aggressively.

text: The specification of the 'believer' in the two previous verses should not be understood as permitting the killing of inviolable persons (Ma'sum) among non-believers, such as Dhimmis, Mu'ahids (covenanted), and Musta'mins (protected). However, He specified the believer to show that killing him is greater and more heinous, because his right upon his believing brother is greater and larger. Indeed, Allah has coupled killing without right with associating partners with Allah (Shirk) in more than one verse in His Book, as in His saying: {And those who do not invoke with Allah another deity or kill the soul which Allah has forbidden [to be killed], except by right, and do not commit unlawful sexual intercourse. And whoever should do that will meet a penalty. Multiplied for him is the punishment on the Day of Resurrection, and he will abide therein humiliated} [Al-Furqan: 68-69]. And His saying: {Say, 'Come, I will recite what your Lord has prohibited to you. [He commands] that you not associate anything with Him...'} to His saying: {And do not kill the soul which Allah has forbidden, except by right} [Al-An'am: 151]. Ibn Hazm said: "There is no sin with Allah Almighty after Shirk greater than two things: One of them is intentionally leaving a mandatory prayer until its time exits. The second is killing a believing man or woman intentionally without right" (1). Al-Shafi'i said: "And there is nothing greater than it [meaning killing without right] after Shirk" (2).

text: Indeed, Allah made killing a single soul without right like killing all people, and saving it like saving all people. He Almighty said: {Because of that, We decreed upon the Children of Israel that whoever kills a soul unless for a soul or for corruption [done] in the land - it is as if he had slain mankind entirely} [Al-Ma'idah: 32]. In this verse: Aggravation of the matter of killing, extreme exaggeration in deterring from it, and emphasis on the right of human life, so that no one is harmed in it without right (1). And His saying (and whoever saves it) implies encouragement to pardon the one whose killing has become obligatory [i.e., due to retribution but forgiven by family], and rescuing those involved in deadly situations like drowning, burning, or an enemy (2). First: That each of them is disobedient to Allah and His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, violating His command, exposing himself to His punishment. Each of them has incurred Allah's wrath and curse, deserves eternal residence in the fire of Hell, and has a great punishment prepared for him. Among them: Allah - Glory be to Him - made the believers in their mutual love, mercy, and connection like a single body; if one member complains, the rest of the body calls out to it with fever and sleeplessness. If the killer destroys a member of this body, it is as if he destroyed the rest of the body and pained all its members. So whoever harms one believer, it is as if he harmed all believers, and in harming all believers is the harm of all people, for Allah defends people by means of the believers among them. text: Among the famous stories that indicate the heinousness of killing and its evil consequence is the story of Usama bin Zaid, may Allah be pleased with them both. Let us listen to him as he says: "The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, sent us to Al-Huraqa from Juhaynah. He said: We attacked the people in the morning and defeated them. I and a man from the Ansar caught up with a man from them. When we overcame him, he said: 'There is no god but Allah.' The Ansari held back from him, but I stabbed him with my spear until I killed him. When we returned, that reached the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, so he said to me: 'O Usama, did you kill him after he said La ilaha illa Allah?' I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, he was only seeking refuge/protection.' He said: 'Did you kill him after he said La ilaha illa Allah?' He kept repeating it to me until I wished I had not become Muslim before that day." This man was a disbeliever fighting Muslims, and when he was certain he would be killed, he accepted Islam outwardly in a manner containing clear doubt. Yet, the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, regarded his killing with severe gravity and rebuked Usama with this great rebuke, until Usama wished he had lost his previous good deeds and precedence in religion and that he had been safe from the consequence of his killing, the omen of this sin, and its evil outcome, and that he had only accepted Islam on that day.

text: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not suffice with what was mentioned regarding the sanctity of blood and explaining its danger. Rather, he emphasized its prohibition and instilled reverence and magnification for it in souls by comparing it to what Muslims have agreed upon revering and magnifying: the Sacred City and the Sacred Month. This was on a witnessed day, in a blessed place, and a great gathering attended by more than one hundred thousand Muslims, when he addressed the people on the Day of Sacrifice at Mina during the Farewell Pilgrimage. In the two Sahihs, on the authority of Ibn Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both, said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said during the Farewell Pilgrimage: "'Behold, which month do you know to be most sacred?' They said: 'Behold, this month of ours.' He said: 'Behold, which land do you know to be most sacred?' They said: 'Behold, this land of ours.' He said: 'Behold, which day do you know to be most sacred?' They said: 'Behold, this day of ours.' He said: 'Verily, Allah the Blessed and Exalted has forbidden your blood, your wealth, and your honor upon you, except by its right, like the sanctity of this day of yours, in this land of yours, in this month of yours. Behold, have I conveyed?' Three times. They answered him each time: 'Behold, yes.' He said: 'Woe to you, or Wylakum! Do not return after me as disbelievers striking the necks of one another'" (1). Indeed, the Prophetic Sunnah has indicated that aggression against an animal by taking its life unjustly and aggressively is a crime whose perpetrator deserves entering the Fire.

text: The Second Topic: The Prohibition of Forbidding Evil if it Necessitates What is More Evil. Enjoining good and forbidding evil were legislated solely to acquire interests (benefits) and repel corruptions (harms). Therefore, they fall under a magnificent, well-known rule upon which all rulings of the Sharia revolve: the rule of 'Interests and Corruptions (Masalih and Mafasid).' (1) Thus, if enjoining good and forbidding evil causes the loss of an interest greater than the interest of performing them, or brings about a corruption greater than the corruption of leaving them, then commanding and forbidding in this case is prohibited, because it contradicts the wisdom for which they were legislated. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah said: 'If enjoining good and forbidding evil are among the greatest obligations or recommended acts, then the obligations and recommendations must act so that the benefit within them outweighs the harm. It is for this that the Messengers were sent and the Books revealed, and Allah does not love corruption. Rather, everything Allah commanded is reform (Salah), and Allah has praised reform and the reformers, and those who believe and do righteous deeds, and He condemned corruption and corrupters in many places. Thus, wherever the harm of commanding and forbidding is greater than its benefit, it is not part of what Allah commanded, even if a duty was abandoned and a prohibition committed; for the believer must fear Allah concerning Allah's servants, and he is not responsible for their guidance.' (2)

text: And he is not forbidden from an evil if it necessitates missing a good that is greater than it. Rather, the prohibition in that case would be from the category of blocking the path of Allah, and striving for the removal of His obedience and the obedience of His Messenger (peace be upon him), and the removal of doing good deeds. And if the evil is predominant, it is forbidden, even if it necessitates the loss of a lesser good associated with it. Commanding that good which necessitates the evil exceeding it would be a command to do evil, and a striving in disobedience to Allah and His Messenger. And if the good and evil that are inseparable are equal, they are neither commanded nor forbidden. Sometimes commanding is appropriate, sometimes forbidding is appropriate, and sometimes neither commanding nor forbidding is appropriate, where the evil and good are inseparable; this applies to specific occurrences. As for the generic type, good is commanded absolutely, and evil is forbidden absolutely. Regarding a single actor or a single group: its good is commanded and its evil is forbidden, its praiseworthy aspects are praised and its blameworthy aspects are blamed, such that the command to do good does not imply the loss of a greater good or the occurrence of an evil exceeding it, nor does the prohibition of evil imply the occurrence of what is more evil than it, or the loss of a good that is weightier than it.

text: Ibn al-Qayyim said: 'The Prophet (peace be upon him) legislated for his nation the obligation of denying evil so that by its denial, a good that Allah and His Messenger love is achieved. If denying the evil necessitates what is more evil than it and more detested by Allah and His Messenger, then denying it is not permissible, even if Allah detests it and abhors its people. This is like denying [the actions of] kings and governors by rebelling against them, for that is the foundation of every evil and sedition (fitnah) until the end of time. text: 14- If that severe threat is for killing individual Covenanters, Dhimmis, and Musta'mins, then how about blowing up their houses and buildings, demolishing them upon their heads, and killing those inside them of women and children? Given that killing these categories among combatant disbelievers is forbidden and not permissible by the consensus of scholars except for necessity, then how about the women and children of those whose blood is inviolable? 15- Enjoining good and forbidding evil become prohibited if they imply the loss of a greater interest or the bringing about of a greater sedition (fitnah) and corruption. 16- It is not permissible for individual subjects to draw weapons to deny evils and fight the people of falsehood, for this is among the exclusive rights of the Imam or whom he deputizes. Individual subjects cannot independently undertake it, because it leads to inciting sedition, the raging of corruption, the destruction of security, and the abundance of killing and confusion. And praise be to Allah by Whose grace good deeds are completed.
